WRITING.TEXT: Probably a heater line to keep the pipe from freezing. Like this - http://www.homedepot.com/p/Frost-King-6-ft-Electric-Water-Pipe-Heat-Cable-HC6A/202262328

As someone who does genealogy and enjoys data visualization, this is great. Can you provide more details on the process? Did you export a GEDCOM, transform and import? I'll have to give something similar a try sometime.

That's actually the wrong brand. The logo on those is a shield and yours has the state of Illinois. Yours is a White Hall #3 crock like one of these: http://www.antiquesnavigator.com/d-1070098/antique-white-hall-illinois-sps-stoneware-pottery-2-storage-crock-jar.html http://www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/large-6-gal-white-hall-illinois-s-p-s-stoneware

A mallet is one of the introductory woodturning projects that many people make. It has the look of a hobby made one instead of a commercial one, so it's very possible it was made as part of a class and never used.

As a woodturner I'll add that the "lines made with heat" is a pretty accurate assessment. Such decorations are made by making a small notch while it's spinning on the lathe and then applying friction (often with a metal wire) to heat up the wood as it spins until it discolors.
Yes, it's the arm cuff for a rifle strap for target shooting. Probably from old school Olympic style small bore shooting.
